block.p: Officials Say North Korea Is Nearing Nuclear Test White House and Pentagon officials are monitoring satellite photographs of North Korea that appear to show preparations for a nuclear weapons test, according to American and foreign officials.

Blair Victory but a Weaker Grip Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain returned to power for a third successive term, but with a much reduced majority reflecting his unpopularity over the war in Iraq, according to official election results.

Normality Amid the Violence In the violence that has affected so many lives across Iraq in recent weeks, there are stories of people coping with the barrage of car bombs and kidnappings that have become so much a part of life.
A suicide bomber blew himself up outside an Iraqi Army base, killing at least 13 people, an Interior Ministry official said.

Palestinians Hold Elections Palestinians held local elections in more than 80 towns and villages in a test for the new Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, with his Fatah movement facing a strong challenge from the Islamic faction Hamas.

A Fight Over Bolton Documents Senate Democrats are threatening to abandon an agreement to move toward a vote on the nomination of John R. Bolton unless the State Department provides documents related to a clash between Mr. Bolton and intelligence officials over Syria.

School Board in Kansas Puts Evolution on Trial In Kansas, which is poised to push through science standards requiring that evolution be challenged in the state's classrooms, a number of critics testified before the Board of Education about the flaws they saw in Darwin's theory.

Arrests in 'Precious Doe' Case Officials in Kansas City have identified the remains of a girl whose body was found four years ago. Her mother and stepfather have been arrested in connection with her death.

A Reversal on Forest Roads The Bush administration supplanted a Clinton-era rule banning road construction in nearly 60 million acres of national forest with a prescription for state-by state decisions on which areas should retain protections.
Defense Begins at Jackson Trial Two young men who said they shared a bed many times with Michael Jackson when they were boys said emphatically that he had never molested them.
Calling All Time Travelers Students at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have organized what they call the first convention for time travelers,.
A Brighter Earth Reversing a decades-long trend toward ''global dimming,'' the earth's surface has become brighter since 1990, scientists reported.

Mayor Proposes Budget With Election-Year Goodies Mayor Bloomberg said New York City would end the current fiscal year with a record $3.3 billion surplus, and proposed a budget of nearly $50 billion for next year that includes cutting taxes and increasing spending on education and sanitation services.

Small Explosion in Midtown Two crude yet powerful explosive devices went off outside a Manhattan office building. No one was injured, but because the building houses the British Consulate, and because it was Election Day in Britain, the blasts prompted brief security measures at other British consulates.

Stamford Mayor Cleared Dannel P. Malloy has been cleared of any wrongdoing by Connecticut's top prosecutor after an inquiry into allegations that he had shown favoritism to contractors who had worked on his house or made contributions to his campaign.
David H. Hackworth A highly-decorated former Army officer who became a combat legend in Vietnam, he was 74.

Ratings Cut for G.M. and Ford General Motors and the Ford Motor Company lost their investment grade ratings, pushing two of corporate America's biggest borrowers into the ranks of junk bonds and rattling the financial markets.

Ex-A.I.G. Chief Investigated Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have opened a criminal investigation into whether Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chairman and chief executive of the American International Group, orchestrated an effort to manipulate the company's stock price in his final weeks as chief, people briefed on the inquiry said.
Editorials: A rising China; bringing back the 30-year bond; the bedfellow disclosure bill; where no fish swim.
Columns: Paul Krugman, Thomas L. Friedman.
